name: Common Teal
description: The male has a brown head with a wide green stripe from the eye to the nape, narrowly white-edged. The body is densely black-and-white striped. Females are brownish with a white chin and belly.
spread_note: Breeds in northern Eurasia and North America, winters in southern parts of these continents and partly in North Africa
food_note: Seeds and green parts of aquatic and wetland plants, invertebrates and their larvae, tadpoles, etc.
image_alt: Common Teal, photo: Prague Zoo Archive
proportions: Body length 22–24.5 cm, tail length 5.5–8 cm, wing length 17–20 cm, weight 0.2–0.5 kg
reproduction: The female lays 6–10 eggs, incubating alone for 23 days.
attractions: It stays in shallow water near the shore and nests in dense reed or bulrush stands. It’s the smallest of Europe’s dabbling ducks.
breeding: First records date from 1992, though they may have appeared earlier.
